questions.text: A child presented to the casualty with tetanic spasms and hypocalcemia. The mother complains of repeated hospitalizations with recurrent infections. On X-ray the thymic shadow was absent. Anomaly to which of the following structure given below is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation of the child with hypocalcemia, recurrent infections, and absent thymic shadow on X-ray is consistent with DiGeorge Syndrome. It occurs due to chromosome 22q11.2 deletion.
  • In this condition, there is a developmental anomaly in the formation of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches, which give rise to the thymus and parathyroid glands. As a result, there is aplasia or hypoplasia of the thymus and parathyroid glands, leading to immunodeficiency(T cell defect and defective cellular immunity) and hypocalcemia, respectively.
  • Third and fourth pharyngeal pouches - depicted by 'C' in the image.
        
Reference: Langman’s Medical Embryology 14 edition page no 290,291 .

questions.text: The X refers to a group of muscles in hand. Amongst X - Muscle (1) is supplied by which nerve?
questions.solution:

  • The first and the second lumbrical are innervated by the median nerve.

questions.text: Structures arranged from anterior to posterior in lung's hilum?

questions.text: Which of these is not a branch of the facial artery?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Superior gluteal nerve supplies all of the following muscles given below except?
questions.solution:
• The superior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fascia lata muscles, but it does not supply the piriformis muscle.
  • The piriformis muscle is supplied by the branches of the sacral plexus, specifically the nerve to the piriformis(formed by the anterior rami of S1/S2 spinal nerves). 


Reference : Gray’s Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition - page no 1318,1330,1374 .

questions.text: Which among the following is formed by 3 bones?
questions.solution:
• Foramen Magnum is a large opening in the base of the skull that is formed by the occipital bone and allows the spinal cord to pass through.
  • Jugular Foramen is a foramen located at the base of the skull, formed by the temporal and occipital bones, which allows the passage of the internal jugular vein and cranial nerves IX, X, and XI.
  • Foramen Rotundum is a small, circular foramen in the sphenoid bone of the skull, which is formed by the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, and allows the passage of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2).
  • Foramen Lacerum is a jagged opening located at the base of the skull, formed by the sphenoid, temporal, and occipital bones, which is filled with cartilage in life and allows the passage of blood vessels and nerves.
Hence, Foramen Lacerum is formed by three bones. 





Reference : Gray’s Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition - page no 422,423,430 .

questions.text: Which of the marked structure is a merocrine gland?
questions.solution:
• In the given skin histology image - 'D' points toward Sweat glands which are Merocrine in nature
  • B points towards sebaceous glands which are holocrine in nature. 
Merocrine glands
Exocrine glands and their secretions are categorized as merocrine and a cell is considered merocrine if its secretions are ejected onto a body surface or into the lumen via exocytosis from secretory cells into a duct or ducts with an epithelial wall.

Holocrine glands
Holocrine glands are a type of exocrine glands that release their secretions by the rupture and disintegration of entire cells. Eg Sebaceous Glands, Meibomian Glands


Junqueira’s Basic Histology: Text and Atlas, 13th Edition - Page no 90,92,387,388 .

questions.text: Damage to the structure producing the elevation in the marked area leads to paralysis of which of the following muscle?
questions.solution:

Hence, damage to the structure producing elevation means damage to the facial nerve fibers and it would result in paralysis of muscles supplied by the facial nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is not restricted in the diet in a patient suffering from Maple syrup urine disease?
questions.solution:
• Methionine is not restricted in Maple syrup urine disease.
  • Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is caused by a deficiency of branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC).
  • The BCKDC is responsible for breaking down the branched-chain amino acids leucine, isoleucine, and valine. Therefore, these three amino acids are restricted in the diet of individuals with this condition. However, methionine metabolism is not affected and can be consumed as part of a normal diet.

Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 566 .

questions.text: Uracil as a nitrogenous base was found in the genetic code of an individual. Which vitamin deficiency could lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
• The conversion of uracil to thymine requires the enzyme thymidylate synthase, which uses a form of folate called 5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate (5,10-MTHF) as a cofactor.
  • Folate deficiency can lead to a decrease in the availability of 5,10-MTHF, which can impair the conversion of uracil to thymine and result in the incorporation of uracil into DNA instead of thymine

Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 537 .

questions.text: Banding technique used for dicentric chromosome?
questions.solution:
Dicentric chromosomes are the ones having two centromeres and C banding is the technique used for staining dicentric chromosomes.

questions.text: Dideoxy Nucleotide Triphosphate (dd NTP's) in Sanger's sequencing technique are used for?
questions.solution:
• Dideoxy nucleotide triphosphates (ddNTPs) are used in Sanger sequencing to terminate DNA polymerization.
  • Sanger sequencing is a method for determining the nucleotide sequence of a DNA fragment. In this method, DNA is synthesized in vitro using a DNA template, a DNA polymerase enzyme, and a mixture of deoxyribonucleotide triphosphates (dNTPs), which are the building blocks of DNA.
  • In addition to the dNTPs, the reaction mixture also contains a small amount of one of four different ddNTPs, each labeled with a different fluorescent dye. These ddNTPs lack a hydroxyl group on the 3' carbon of the sugar, which prevents further nucleotide addition after they are incorporated into the growing DNA chain.
  • As a result, the polymerase enzyme randomly incorporates the ddNTPs into the newly synthesized DNA chain, leading to the termination of the chain elongation at different positions.
  • The resulting mixture of DNA fragments of different lengths, terminated at different positions, can then be separated by size using gel electrophoresis, and the sequence can be determined based on the order of the labeled ddNTPs that are detected using a fluorescence scanner.

Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 26,27,439 .

questions.text: Eicosanoids are formed from?
questions.solution:
• Eicosanoids are a group of signaling molecules that are formed from arachidonic acid, an omega-6 fatty acid.
  • Examples of eicosanoids include Prostaglandins/ Thromboxanes / Leukotrienes / Lipoxins etc.


Reference: K.D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page no 197-199 .

questions.text: Deamination of methylated cytosine will form?
questions.solution:
• Deamination involves the removal of an amino group (-NH2) from the cytosine molecule, which results in the formation of uracil.
  • However, since the starting material, methylated cytosine, has a methyl group (-CH3) attached to the nitrogen atom that would normally be deaminated, the deamination reaction results in the conversion of methylated cytosine to thymine.


Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 335,370.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition shown in the graph below (red line in the presence of inhibitor).
questions.solution:
In the above graph - Vmax is the same while 1/Km is decreased - hence, Km has increased. This indicates Competitive inhibition.

Competitive Inhibition
 
  • Competitive inhibition is a type of enzyme inhibition where the inhibitor molecule competes with the substrate molecule for binding to the active site of the enzyme. This type of inhibition can affect the Michaelis constant (Km) of the enzymatic reaction.
  • When a competitive inhibitor binds to the enzyme's active site, it blocks the substrate from binding to the enzyme, which decreases the effective concentration of the enzyme-substrate complex. This, in turn, increases the apparent Km of the enzyme for the substrate.
  • In a competitive inhibition scenario, the Vmax of the enzymatic reaction is not affected, as the inhibitor only affects the rate of substrate binding to the enzyme. The Vmax can still be achieved if enough substrate is present to overcome the inhibitor's effect

  Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 77-81 .

questions.text: DNA - protein interaction can be studied by using?
questions.solution:
• DNA-protein interactions can be studied by several methods, but one of the most effective ways is through DNAse footprinting.
  • In this technique, a protein is allowed to bind to DNA, and then the complex is treated with DNAse, an enzyme that cleaves DNA at random locations.
  • However, the enzyme cannot cleave the DNA when it is bound to the protein, creating a region of protected DNA. This region is called a "footprint," and it reveals the specific sequence where the protein is bound to the DNA.
  • The DNA fragments are then separated by gel electrophoresis and visualized to determine the location of the protein-DNA complex.

Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 341,445,451 .

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Human Genome Project?
questions.solution:
The false statement regarding the Human Genome Project is: Took 2 years to complete

The Human Genome Project was a large-scale international research project that aimed to sequence and map the entire human genome. It was a long-term endeavor that spanned over a decade, not just two years. The project officially began in 1990 and was completed in 2003, taking a total of approximately 13 years to finish.

To summarize the correct statements:

  • Collaboration of many countries: True. The Human Genome Project involved the collaboration of multiple countries around the world, including the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Japan, and others.
  • Around 20,000 genes were identified & sequenced: As part of the project, scientists identified and sequenced approximately 20,000-25,000 protein-coding genes within the human genome.
  • Used modern sequencing techniques: The Human Genome Project utilized modern sequencing techniques and technologies, such as automated DNA sequencing, to decipher the sequence of base pairs in the human genome.
  

Reference : Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 3, 701 .

N-MYC is an oncogenic marker of Neuroblastoma.

questions.text:
A gene of interest was identified in a lower organism that coded for a particular protein. Arrange the following steps in a sequence to produce the protein of interest using Recombinant DNA technology. 
i- Lysis of bacterial wall
ii- Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria
iii- SDS PAGE
iv- Blotting 
v- Expression of gene to produce protein
questions.solution:
The steps of the Recombinant DNA technique are:

1. Isolation of the gene of Interest
2. Incorporation of the gene into the vector (plasmid) - This process utilizes Restriction endonucleases/Ligases
3. Insert vector in E. Coli (host)
4. Expression of the gene in E. Coli for the production of protein
5. Bacterial wall lysis
6. Electrophoresis(SDS -PAGE)
7. Western blotting/Hybridisation
8. Elution of protein.

 

Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition , Page no 37, 449, 432-450 .

questions.text: Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS) is used to relieve pain. What is the principle behind this?
questions.solution:
• The principle behind Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS) for pain relief is the Gate Control Theory of Pain.
  • The Gate Control Theory of Pain suggests that non-painful input can close the "gates" to painful input, which prevents pain sensations from reaching the brain. TENS works by delivering low-level electrical impulses to the skin surface, which stimulates the sensory nerves and activates the non-painful input. This stimulation can close the "gates" to the painful input, reducing the sensation of pain.

   Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th Edition- Page no 169 .

choices.text: Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and phosphate

questions.text: What causes the detachment of the myosin head from the actin active site during muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
• The detachment of the myosin head from the actin active site during muscle contraction is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head.
  • During muscle contraction, the myosin head binds to the actin active site to form a cross-bridge. This cross-bridge is responsible for generating force and movement. When ATP binds to the myosin head, it causes a conformational change that weakens the bond between the myosin head and the actin active site. This leads to the detachment of the myosin head from the actin active site, breaking the cross-bridge.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is option (1) Binding of ATP. The hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and phosphate (option 2) and power stroke (option 4) are involved in the subsequent steps of muscle contraction, while a decrease in sarcoplasmic calcium (option 3) would actually prevent muscle contraction from occurring.
 

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th Edition- Page no 103,104,105 .

questions.text: 2 blood vessels A and B have laminar blood follow. If the diameter and length of vessel B are double that of vessel A as shown below, flow in B will be how many times the flow in A?
questions.solution:
The volume flow rate is
1. Directly proportional to the 4th power of radius and
2. Inversely proportional to the length
 

The volume flow rate is given by Poiseuille's equation which is as follows:

Q = (π * ΔP * r^4) / (8 * η * L)

Where:
1. Q is the flow rate of the fluid,
2. ΔP is the pressure difference across the pipe,
3. r is the radius of the pipe,
4. η is the viscosity of the fluid, and
5. L is the length of the pipe.

The volume flow rate is therefore 
1. Directly proportional to the 4th power of radius and
2. Inversely proportional to the length

If diameter/radius is increased twice  - flow would become 2*2*2*2= 16 times. 
But since length too is increased twice - the actual flow rate would be = 16/2 = 8 times.
Therefore in this case the flow would be 8 times higher.

 

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th Edition- Page no 563 .

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause cyanosis?
questions.solution:
Hypothermia is not a cause of cyanosis.

Cyanosis is a bluish discoloration of the skin, lips, or mucous membranes caused by the presence of deoxygenated hemoglobin(>5g/dL) in the blood vessels near the skin surface. It can be caused by various conditions that result in reduced oxygen levels in the blood.

  • Pulmonary arteriovenous fistula is a rare condition where there is an abnormal connection between an artery and vein in the lung. This can result in a decrease in oxygen levels in the blood, leading to cyanosis.
  • Methemoglobinemia is a condition where there is an increased level of methemoglobin, which is an abnormal form of hemoglobin that cannot bind to oxygen effectively. This can result in a decrease in oxygen levels in the blood and lead to cyanosis.
  • High altitude can cause cyanosis due to decreased oxygen availability at higher altitudes, which can lead to reduced oxygen levels in the blood.
  • Hypothermia is a condition where the body temperature drops below normal levels. It can cause various symptoms, including pale or blue skin, but this is not true cyanosis caused by deoxygenated hemoglobin.

Therefore, the answer is option 4, hypothermia.
 

Reference : Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page no 247 .

questions.text:
The conductance of 2 ions in different colors during different phases of the action potential(in red) is shown below. Which of the following pair of ions corresponds to Blue and Green respectively? 

1. Na+ , Ca2+ 
2. Na+, K+
3. K+, Ca2+
4. Ca2+, Na+
questions.solution:
Action potentials are produced by a series of all-or-none changes in ion permeability brought on by the activity of voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels. Blue corresponds to Na+ conductance driving the depolarisation phase of action potential and green corresponds to K+ conductance driving the repolarisation. 
 

During the different phases of the action potential, there are changes in the permeability of ions, specifically sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+). Here is a summary of Na+ and K+ conductance during each phase:

  1. Resting Phase: The resting phase of the action potential is characterized by a relatively stable membrane potential. At this stage, the Na+ channels are closed, and the K+ channels are mostly closed, resulting in low conductance for both ions.

  2. Depolarization Phase: During the depolarization phase, the membrane potential rapidly becomes more positive. This is primarily due to an increase in Na+ conductance. The opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels allows a rapid influx of Na+ ions into the cell, leading to depolarization.

  3. Repolarization Phase: In the repolarization phase, the membrane potential returns to its resting state. This is primarily driven by an increase in K+ conductance. The opening of voltage-gated K+ channels allows K+ ions to move out of the cell, repolarizing the membrane and restoring the resting potential.

  4. Hyperpolarization Phase: After repolarization, the membrane potential briefly becomes more negative than the resting potential. This is known as the hyperpolarization phase. During this phase, K+ conductance remains relatively high, contributing to hyperpolarization.




     

    Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th Edition- Page no 88,89 .

questions.text: In the following graph line N represents the normal relationship between alveolar ventilation and arterial pCO2, (when pO2 is kept constant at 100 mmHg). If the pH is changed from 7.4 to 7.3 where will the line shift?
questions.solution:
• Chemoreceptors become even more sensitive in acidosis. Thus, a pH decrease results in a further shift to the left. There is higher alveolar ventilation (Denoted by line D) at a lower PCO2 due to the high sensitivity of chemoreceptors to low pH (acidosis) 
  • B and C denote changes due to hypoxia (pO2) - B occurs when pO2 decrease, and C when pO2 increases. A is the baseline. 
  • When both hypoxia and acidosis occur together - alveolar ventilation increase maximum - denoted by line E.

      

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th Edition- Page no 651,652  .

questions.text: AIDS defining illness include all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Kaposi sarcoma, Cervical carcinoma, and Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma are Malignancies associated with HIV which are considered to be AIDS-defining in nature. HIV is also associated with other malignancies like Hodgkins, Melanoma etc. but they are not considered AIDS-defining illnesses.

questions.text: Clotting factor that is decreased in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• During Pregnancy, the hemostasis tends to change towards hypercoagulability. (in order to decrease blood loss at the time of delivery).

questions.text: Ratio of T and B lymphocytes in peripheral blood?
questions.solution:
In peripheral blood, T lymphocytes comprise approximately 70-75% of all Lymphocytes while the remaining 20-25% of Lymphocytes are B- Lymphocytes. Hence, The correct answer to the above question is 3:1.

questions.text: Antigen bound MHC class I binds and activates which of the following?

choices.text: In Crohn's disease there is only mucosal involvement

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding inflammatory Bowel disease?
questions.solution:
The true statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease is: Crohn's disease has skip lesions.

The other statements are incorrect:

  1. While there is a genetic component to inflammatory bowel disease, it is not completely understood, and both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis have a genetic predisposition.
  2. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the digestive tract, from the mouth to the anus, and can involve the entire thickness of the intestinal wall, not just the mucosa.
  3. Ulcerative colitis only affects the colon and rectum and typically involves only the mucosa, not the entire intestinal wall.
 

Reference : Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page no 2469,2474-2476,2482-2484 .

questions.text: 45-year-old woman presented with easy fatiguability. On examination, she was found to be pale and her Hb was 6 gm%. Which of the following feature is most likely to be seen in the peripheral smear of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Based on the given information, the most likely feature to be seen in the peripheral smear of this patient is "Microcytic hypochromic RBCs."
  • Microcytic hypochromic RBCs are seen in conditions such as Iron deficiency anemia, which is the most common cause of anemia worldwide.
  • Iron is an essential component for the production of hemoglobin, and its deficiency leads to small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic) RBCs.
  • Other causes of microcytic hypochromic anemia include thalassemia and anemia of chronic disease.
 

Reference : Robbins and Crotan Pathological Basis of Disease , 10th Edition Page no 655,657,658,816 .

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Anemia of Chronic disease?
questions.solution:
Anemia of Chronic disease has 'high' levels of Ferritin, not low. 

Anemia of Chronic Disease
 
  • Anemia of chronic disease (ACD) is a type of anemia that occurs in individuals with chronic inflammatory or infectious diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, and chronic kidney disease.
  • In ACD, increase in the levels of hepcidin reduces the release of iron from stores, leading to a decrease in the amount of iron available for the production of red blood cells, and hence, anemia.
  • In ACD, the levels of ferritin in the blood are typically elevated due to increased iron storage in the RES system, such as the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. The elevation of ferritin in ACD can be useful in distinguishing it from iron-deficiency anemia, where ferritin levels are usually low.


 

Reference : Robbins and Crotan Pathological Basis of Disease , 10th Edition Page no 658,659,848 .

questions.text: Which among the following is an X linked dominant disorder?
questions.solution:
• Rett syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder caused by a mutation in the MECP2 gene.
  • It affects mainly females, with a prevalence of 1 in 10,000.
  • The clinical features of Rett syndrome include regression of acquired skills, repetitive hand movements, breathing abnormalities, seizures, and intellectual disability.
  • It follows an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern. 

Inheritance patterns and defective genes of other disorders mentioned in the options



 

Reference : Robbins and Crotan Pathological Basis of Disease , 10th Edition Page no 1285,1286,1302 .

questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with arthritis of knee and lesions on the hands as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image shows Gottron's papule in Juvenile Dermatomyositis.
  • Gottron's papules are considered a classic cutaneous manifestation of juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM).
  • They are raised, scaly, violaceous papules or plaques that appear symmetrically on the knuckles, elbows, and knees.

questions.text: Serum markers in a person diagnosed as chronic hepatitis B are all except?
questions.solution:
• Anti HBs antibody is not a marker of chronic hepatitis B infection.
  • It is a marker of immunity to hepatitis B infection. It is produced in response to a hepatitis B vaccination or a patient who has recovered from a Hepatitis B infection and is now immune. 
  • A person with chronic hepatitis B will have HBsAg, Anti-HBC, and HBV DNA in their blood. They will not have Anti HBs antibodies in their blood.





 

 Reference : Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition page no 2571 table 339-2 .

questions.text: In India Pretransfusion routine blood screening is done for all except?
questions.solution:
In India, pretransfusion routine blood screening is done for all except dengue (option 4)

The following blood-borne infections are screened for in India:

1. HIV
2. Hepatitis B
3. Hepatitis C
4. Syphilis
5. Malaria
 

Dengue is not routinely screened for in India.

 

Reference : Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 672.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presented with pain in the lower limb. X ray showed a lesson at the tibial diaphysis with reactions visible on the surface of the bone. Histopathology of the lesion showed small round cells, the lesion is positive for MIC2 on immunohistochemistry. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical stem and histopathology/IHC description matches Ewing's sarcoma. (Diaphyseal tumor in an adolescent boy having Small round Blue cell histopathology and MIC2 positivity)

Ewing's Sarcoma 
  • The histopathology of Ewing sarcoma is characterized by the presence of small, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. (It's a Small round Blue cell tumor). Necrosis and mitotic figures are commonly seen.
  • The following IHC markers are commonly used for Ewing sarcoma:
  1. CD99(Also known as MIC2): This is the most sensitive marker(but not specific) for Ewing sarcoma. It is positive in more than 90% of cases.
  2. FLI-1
  3. NKX2.2: More specific than CD99 for Ewing's Sarcoma. 
  • The combination of CD99/NKX2.2 is very specific for Ewing sarcoma.


 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1192,1193, 1188,477,478.

questions.text:
Most common ectopic tissue found in meckel's diverticulum? 
(i) Gastric 
(ii) Colonic 
(iii) Pancreatic 
(iv) Adrenals
questions.solution:
Ectopic gastric tissue and ectopic pancreatic tissue are two of the most common types of abnormal tissue that can develop in Meckel's diverticulum.

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy presents with recurrent watery stools and diarrhea, atopic dermatitis, petechia and a platelet count of 20,000/mm3. Which among the following is the confirmatory step for a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical stem describes the classical triad of Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome in an 11 month old boy. 
  • Atopic dermatitis
  • Thrombocytopenia (petechia and platelet count of 20,000)
  •  Immunodeficiency (repeated watery stools and diarrhea)
Hence, the confirmatory step for diagnosis would be option(1) - WASP gene testing(present on chromosome X )

questions.text: Differential expression of genetic material is seen in?
questions.solution:
The differential expression of genetic material is observed in Genomic Imprinting (option 2)

Genomic Imprinting 

  • Genomic imprinting refers to an epigenetic phenomenon where specific genes are expressed in a parent-of-origin-dependent manner.
  • This means that certain genes are expressed differently depending on whether they are inherited from the mother or the father. In genomic imprinting, one copy of the gene is typically "imprinted" or marked during gamete formation, resulting in gene expression being restricted to either the paternal or maternal allele.

Diseases involving Genomic imprinting include

  • Prader-Willi syndrome: Intellectual disability, obesity, and behavioral problems. Caused by a loss of function of genes on the paternal chromosome 15. ( P for Prader, P for paternal)
  • Angelman syndrome:  intellectual disability, developmental delays, and seizures(Happy Puppet). Caused by a loss of function of genes on the maternal chromosome 15. (A for Angelman, A for amma(mother) 
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome:  Rapid growth, hemihypertrophy, abdominal wall defects and an increased risk of Wilm/RMS/Gonadoblastoma etc. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is caused by an overgrowth of cells in the placenta during pregnancy. This can lead to an increase in the number of copies of imprinted genes on the short arm of chromosome 11.(WT2)
 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 144,175,178,179,180,1285.

questions.text: Identify the test given in the image.

In order to target particular chromosomal sites in the nucleus, fluorescent DNA probes are used. Under a fluorescent microscope, the colored signals generated are observed.

questions.text: Neurosecretory granules are typically seen in all of the given malignancies except?
questions.solution:
• Neurosecretory granules are typically seen in neuroendocrine tumors, which are characterized by the presence of cells with neuroendocrine features.
  • The malignancy that does not typically exhibit neurosecretory granules among the given options is option (4) Adrenal cortical tumor.
Adrenal cortical tumor
  • Adrenal cortical tumors, such as adrenal cortical carcinoma or adenoma, arise from the adrenal cortex and are typically not associated with neurosecretory granules.
  • These tumors primarily involve the production of steroid hormones, such as cortisol or aldosterone, rather than neuroendocrine hormones.
 

On the other hand, the remaining options( Medullary thyroid carcinoma/ Pituatory adenoma and Paraganglioma) are known to be associated with neurosecretory granules.


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1119,1120,1091,1067,1070,746 .

questions.text: Identify the cells stained by Toluidine blue?

questions.text: Which among the following is a marker of NK cells?

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of innate immunity?
questions.solution:
The component that is not a part of innate immunity among the given options is B lymphocytes. 

B-lymphocytes
B-lymphocytes are primarily associated with adaptive immunity rather than innate immunity. B-lymphocytes play a crucial role in adaptive immunity by producing antibodies, which are specific proteins that recognize and bind to specific antigens.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in pleomorphic adenoma
questions.solution:
• Perineural invasion refers to the infiltration of tumor cells into the nerve fibers.
  • It is more commonly associated with malignant tumors rather than benign tumors like pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign salivary gland tumor characterized by the presence of myoepithelial cells and chondroid differentiation, but it does not typically exhibit perineural invasion.

questions.text: Which among the following statement is true regarding autophagy?
questions.solution:
• The true statement regarding autophagy is: 4. It fuses with a lysosome to form an autophagolysosome.
  • Degradation of worn, aberrant, or defective cellular components occurs within organelles called lysosomes and is referred to as autophagy, also known as autophagocytosis. 
  • During autophagy, a double-membrane structure called the autophagosome forms around the targeted cellular material, such as damaged organelles or proteins.
  • The autophagosome then fuses with a lysosome, forming an autophagolysosome. Inside the autophagolysosome, the targeted material is degraded by lysosomal enzymes, and the resulting molecules are recycled for cellular use.
 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 42,44,45,46,47,48 .

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of partial aneuploidy?
questions.solution:
• Cri du chat syndrome is a genetic disorder that occurs when a part of chromosome 5 is missing. (Deletion of short arm of chromosome 5). This condition is also known as 5p - (5p minus) syndrome.
 
  • The name "cri du chat" comes from the French term for "cry of the cat," which describes the distinctive cry that infants with this condition may produce.
 
  • Partial aneuploidy refers to a condition where there is an abnormal number of chromosomes, but only a portion of a chromosome is affected.



Reference: Cerruti Mainardi, Paola. “Cri du Chat syndrome.” Orphanet journal of rare diseases vol. 1 33. 5 Sep. 2006, doi:10.1186/1750-1172-1-33. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1574300/

questions.text: Which of the following is true about clear cell renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option 1-  It is mostly sporadic is the correct answer.

Other options
  • Option(2)Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is commonly associated with genetic alterations, including the deletion of the short arm of chromosome 3 (3p) and the loss of the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor gene.
  • Option (3)Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common subtype of renal cell carcinoma, not the least common. 
  • Option (4) Clear cell renal cell carcinoma originates from the cells of the proximal convoluted tubules (PCT) of the kidney, not the distal convoluted tubules (DCT).

    

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 948-951 .

questions.text: Cell in cell appearance is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Entosis is a phenomenon where one cell invades and takes up residence inside another cell. This process is known as "cell-in-cell" formation and can occur in various physiological and pathological conditions. Entosis has been observed in many types of cells, including epithelial cells, immune cells, and cancer cells.
  • During entosis, a cell actively engulfs another cell, forming a structure called an entotic vacuole. The engulfed cell can survive for a period of time within the entotic vacuole, but eventually, it undergoes cell death or is extruded from the host cell. The mechanism underlying entosis is not fully understood, but it is believed to involve changes in adhesion molecules, actin cytoskeleton, and apoptotic pathways.

   

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 39,40,42,44,46,47 .

questions.text:
Match the following 
A. Teratoma (i) Lymphocytic infiltrate
B. Dysgerminoma (ii) Neuroepithelium, hair, cartilage present
C. Yolk sac tumor (iii) Cell Exner bodies
D. Granulosa cell tumor (iv) Schiller duval bodies
questions.solution:
• Cell Exner bodies are characteristic histological findings seen in granulosa cell tumors (GCTs) of the ovary. These bodies are small, eosinophilic, and round structures found within the tumor cells. They are believed to represent accumulations of fluid-filled spaces or secretory material within the tumor.


 
  • Schiller-Duval bodies are small, spherical structures found in the endodermal sinus cells of germ cell tumors(yolk sac tumors). These structures are formed by a central capillary surrounded by layers of tumor cells arranged in a rosette-like pattern. The appearance of these structures is often described as resembling a glomerulus, a small cluster of blood vessels found in the kidney.


 
  • Teratomas are composed of tissues derived from all three germ cell layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. As a result, teratomas exhibit a wide range of histopathological features and can contain different types of tissue, including elements such as skin, hair, teeth, cartilage, muscle, bone, and nervous tissue.


 
  • Dysgerminomas are composed of sheets or nests of large, round cells with well-defined cell borders. The cells have abundant clear or eosinophilic cytoplasm. They often show a prominent lymphocytic infiltrate within the tumor tissue. The lymphocytes can surround the tumor cells or infiltrate between them.



 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1024,1025,1026,1028 .

questions.text: Ovarian tumor histopathology is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image depicts Schiller-Duval bodies found in Yolk sac tumors. 
  • Schiller-Duval bodies are small, spherical structures found in the endodermal sinus cells of germ cell tumors such as yolk sac tumors. These structures are formed by a central capillary surrounded by layers of tumor cells arranged in a rosette-like pattern. The appearance of these structures is often described as resembling a glomerulus, a small cluster of blood vessels found in the kidney. 
  • Schiller-Duval bodies are a diagnostic hallmark of yolk sac tumors and are usually identified on histological examination of biopsy specimens. 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1024,1025,1026,1028 .

questions.text: In which airborne disease is isolation recommended to prevent the spread?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following should be done in case of a mercury spill from a sphygmomanometer?
questions.solution:
In case of a mercury spill, the following steps as given in CPCB guidelines on “Environmentally Sound Techniques for Mercury Waste Generated from Healthcare Facilities” shall be followed:
  1.  A syringe (without a needle) shall be used to suck the beads of mercury.
  2. Collected mercury should be placed slowly and carefully into an unbreakable plastic container/glass bottle with an airtight lid half filled with water.
  3. After removing larger beads, use sticky tape to collect smaller hard-to-see beads. Place the sticky tape in a punctured-proof yellow bag and secure it properly.



DO NOT's while handling a Mercury spill






Reference: CPCB guidelines on “Environmentally Sound Techniques for Mercury Waste Generated from Healthcare Facilities" (2012). URL:  https://cpcb.nic.in/openpdffile.php?id=TGF0ZXN0RmlsZS9MYXRlc3RfNThfR3VpZGVsaW5lc19Gb3JfTWVyY3VyeS5wZGY=

questions.text: Which of the following is a disinfectant but not a sanitizer?
questions.solution:
• Among the options provided, the disinfectant but not a sanitizer is Bleaching powder.
  • Bleaching powder, also known as calcium hypochlorite, is a potent disinfectant commonly used for water treatment and surface disinfection. It is effective in killing a wide range of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi.
  • However, it is primarily used for disinfection rather than as a sanitizer.

questions.text: A 50 year old male with fever for 3 weeks presented to the hospital. Patient did not improve on antibiotics and antimalarial. On examination abdominal distension present. Rk 39 antibody test (+). What is the best treatment option for this condition?
questions.solution:
• The best treatment option for the patient's condition would be: Liposomal Amphotericin B.
  • The positive Rk 39 antibody test suggests a possible diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kala-azar. The treatment of choice for visceral leishmaniasis is liposomal Amphotericin B, which is highly effective and recommended as first-line therapy.
  • Fluconazole is an antifungal medication and would not be the appropriate treatment for visceral leishmaniasis. Pentamidine and sodium stibogluconate are alternative treatment options for visceral leishmaniasis, but liposomal Amphotericin B is considered the best option.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1741,1743-1745 .

questions.text: A forest worker has a H/O warty cauliflower lesion on his foot. The histology of the lesion is shown below. The histology image is of?
questions.solution:
• The forest worker is likely suffering from a fungal infection known as chromoblastomycosis.
  • Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues caused by various dematiaceous (dark-pigmented) fungi.
  • The most common fungi responsible are Cladosporium carrionii, Phialophora verrucosa, and Fonsecaea pedrosoi.
  • The given histopathology image is of sclerotic bodies which are consistent with this diagnosis
  • Sclerotic bodies are the diagnostic feature of chromoblastomycosis. They are thick-walled, copper-colored fungal cells that are typically found in the infected tissue. These bodies are a result of the chronic inflammatory response to the fungal infection. The cells typically tend to divide into multiple planes of division by thick septa. There is marked pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia of the epidermis. 
 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 605,606,608,610,611 .

questions.text: Identify the pathogen based on the cell wall shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The cell wall of Aspergillus fumigatus, a common species of Aspergillus, contains several constituents. The major components of the cell wall include:

  1. Chitin: Chitin is a polysaccharide composed of N-acetylglucosamine units. It provides rigidity and strength to the cell wall.

  2. Glucan: Glucan is a polysaccharide composed of glucose units. It contributes to the integrity of the cell wall and provides structural support.

  3. Mannoproteins: Mannoproteins are glycoproteins that contain mannose residues. They are important for cell wall organization, adhesion, and immune modulation.

  4. β-(1,3)-Glucan: Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall also contains β-(1,3)-glucan, which is another type of polysaccharide composed of glucose units. It is an important target for immune recognition.


    Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 352,393,593,594,612,613 .

questions.text: Which among the following is a mollicute?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, Ureaplasma urealyticum is a mollicute.

  • Mollicutes, also known as mycoplasmas, are a group of bacteria that lack a cell wall.
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum is a species of mycoplasma and belongs to the class Mollicutes. 
  • Associated with urogenital infections- a common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, urinary tract infections etc.

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement regarding chemoprophylaxis in HIV positive patients?
questions.solution:
The wrong statement regarding chemoprophylaxis in HIV-positive patients is:

  1. Pneumocystis prophylaxis is only given if CD4 count >200

The correct approach is to provide pneumocystis prophylaxis when the CD4 count is below a certain threshold, not only when it is above a specific value. Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) prophylaxis is typically recommended when the CD4 count is below 200 cells/mm³ or when the patient has a history of previous PCP infection. Therefore, option 4 is the incorrect statement.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1563,1565,1566,1567 .

Are suggestive of Hymenolepis nana.

questions.text: All of the following are used as first-line treatment in the management of Rheumatoid arthritis except?

questions.text: Which of the following is not a check point inhibitor ?
questions.solution:
The checkpoint inhibitor that is not among the options provided is "Cetuximab" (option 3).

Cetuximab is not a checkpoint inhibitor; it is a monoclonal antibody that targets the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). It is used in the treatment of colorectal/head and neck cancer.

Options 1, 2, and 4 are all checkpoint inhibitors.
Nivolumab (option 1) and pembrolizumab (option 2) are both monoclonal antibodies that target and block the programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) receptor.
Avelumab (option 4) is a monoclonal antibody that targets and blocks the programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1).
 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 1417,1423,1432,1401,801,759 .

questions.text: A pregnant female who was a known case of leprosy developed type 2 lepra reaction. Best treatment for her would be?
questions.solution:
• Type 2 lepra reaction, also known as erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), is an acute inflammatory complication of leprosy. It is characterized by painful skin nodules, fever, malaise, and inflammation in various organs.
 
  • MDT is NOT stopped in Lepra reactions as stopping drug may cause treatment failure. MDT is safe in Pregnancy.
 
  • Thalidomide should not be given to pregnant females due to its known teratogenic effects, which can cause severe birth defects. Hence, in a pregnant female - the option would be to add steroids (option 1).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1387, 1390.

questions.text: Which antidiabetic medication can cause bone fracture in female?

questions.text: A female patient with previous history of mania 1 year back, who is pregnant now presented with an episode of hypomania. Which of the following drug is to be avoided for being highly teratogenic to the fetus?

questions.text: A patient with persecutory delusions and 3rd person auditory hallucinations was diagnosed as schizophrenic and started on risperidone 2.5 mg daily dose and after the previous night's dose, he today presented with his eyes rolling upward for few hours. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical stem describes an 'Oculogyric crisis' which is an EPS(extrapyramidal side effect) secondary to the use of anti-dopaminergic(anti-psychotic) drugs.
  • The oculogyric crisis is an acute dystonic reaction characterized by the sudden and involuntary upward deviation of the eyes. It is commonly associated with certain medications, particularly antipsychotic drugs such as haloperidol, but can also occur as a symptom of other conditions or drug toxicity.
  • The drug of choice for reversing the symptoms is usually an anticholinergic medication such as benztropine/diphenhydramine or Promethazine. By inhibiting acetylcholine activity, they can help alleviate the dystonic reaction and relieve the oculogyric crisis



 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 290, 291,724 .

questions.text: A patient comes to emergency with increased salivation, diarrhea, watery eyes and dysuria. What will be the first line of management?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms mentioned by the patient, including increased salivation, diarrhea, watery eyes, and dysuria, could be indicative of a possible cholinergic crisis.
  • The cholinergic crisis is a condition characterized by excessive stimulation of the parasympathetic nervous system, due an overactivity of acetylcholine.

Possible causes of a cholinergic crisis include:

  1. Organophosphate or carbamate poisoning: Exposure to pesticides or insecticides that inhibit the enzyme acetylcholinesterase can result in excessive accumulation of acetylcholine.
  2. Overdose of cholinergic medications: Excessive use or overdose of medications that enhance cholinergic activity, such as cholinesterase inhibitors or muscarinic agonists, can lead to a cholinergic crisis.
DOC for the management of any drug causing excessive cholinergic activity is using a Muscarinic antagonist like Atropine.

 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 165,167 .

questions.text: Find out right match regarding drug and its side effect?
questions.solution:
The correct match regarding the drug and its side effect is: Verapamil - Constipation

  • Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker used to treat Hypertension. One of the common side effects of verapamil is constipation. It can slow down the movement/peristalsis of the intestines(due to calcium channel blockage), leading to difficulty in passing stools.

The other options do not have the correct drug-side effect match:

  1. Hydralazine is primarily used for hypertension and does not typically cause heart failure.
  2. Atenolol is a beta-blocker commonly used for hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions, but it does not cause hemolytic anemia.
  3. Aliskiren is a renin inhibitor used for hypertension, and it does not typically cause hypokalemia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 530,580 .

questions.text: NAPQI is an intermediate metabolite of which drug toxicity?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is 1. Paracetamol (also known as acetaminophen).
  • NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine) is a toxic metabolite that is formed during the metabolism of paracetamol (acetaminophen) in the liver. In therapeutic doses, paracetamol is primarily metabolized by conjugation with glucuronic acid and sulfate, which are nontoxic pathways.
  • However, when paracetamol is taken in excessive amounts or in the presence of certain risk factors, a significant portion of it is metabolized by the cytochrome P450 enzyme system in the liver, leading to the production of NAPQI.
  • NAPQI is highly reactive and can cause liver damage by depleting glutathione and forming toxic adducts with cellular proteins.
 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 696 .

questions.text: What is the measure of extend of drug absorption?
questions.solution:
• The extent of drug absorption is represented by  AUC (Area Under the Curve). AUC represents the total exposure of a drug in the systemic circulation over time after administration. It provides information about the amount of drug that reaches the systemic circulation.
  • T max (time to reach maximum concentration) and C max (maximum concentration) are measures of the rate of drug absorption rather than the extent.
  • T max indicates the time it takes for a drug to reach its highest concentration in the blood
  • C max represents the peak concentration achieved.
  • T1/2 (half-life) is a measure of the rate of drug elimination and represents the time it takes for the drug concentration to decrease by half in the body. It is not directly related to the extent of drug absorption

 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 32,38 .

questions.text: A company makes T. Paracetamol 500mg, but it has only 250mg of paracetamol. What is this called?
questions.solution:
• The correct term for a situation where a product is labeled with incorrect information regarding its content is "misbranding."
  • Misbranding refers to the labeling or packaging of a product that is false or misleading. In the given scenario, if a company labels a product as containing 500mg of paracetamol when it actually contains only 250mg, it would be considered misbranding.


As per Drugs and Cosmetic Act, 1940 - a drug is deemed to be misbranded:

(a) If it is so colored, coated, powdered, or polished that damage is concealed or if it is made to appear of better or greater therapeutic value than it really is; or

(b) If it is not labeled in the prescribed manner; or

(c) If its container is composed, in whole or in part, of any poisonous or deleterious substance which may render the contents injurious to health; or

(d) If it bears or contains, for purposes of coloring only, a color other than one which is prescribed; or

(e) If it contains any harmful or toxic substance which may render it injurious to health; or

(f) If any substance has been mixed therewith so as to reduce its quality or strength.



Reference: The Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940, Amended in 2016, CDSCO, Page no 10. URL: https://cdsco.gov.in/opencms/export/sites/CDSCO_WEB/Pdf-documents/acts_rules/2016DrugsandCosmeticsAct1940Rules1945.pdf

questions.text: Which is the active metabolite of Cyclophosphamide?
questions.solution:
• The active metabolite of Cyclophosphamide is: 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide.
  • Cyclophosphamide is a prodrug that undergoes metabolic activation in the liver. One of its primary metabolites is 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide, which is responsible for the cytotoxic effects of the drug (along with aldophosphamide).
  • 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide can further metabolize into other active species, including phosphoramide mustard, which is the ultimate cytotoxic compound responsible for the anticancer activity of Cyclophosphamide.
 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1170 .

questions.text: Which antimicrobial agent act by inhibiting transpeptidase enzyme?
questions.solution:
Beta-Lactam antibiotics inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) and inhibiting the transpeptidation step of peptidoglycan synthesis, leading to cell lysis and death. 


 
Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 1148,1146,1147 .

questions.text: Half life of Letrozole is?
questions.solution:
The half-life of Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of breast cancer, is approximately 45 hours (option 1).

The half-life of letrozole is 45 hours.

Letrozole is a reversible aromatase inhibitor.It is a non-steroidal compound that inhibits the aromatization of estrogen thereby causing estrogen depletion.Letrozole is rapidly absorbed with 99.9% oral bioavailability and has a t½ of around 41 hours.Letrozole is used as the first-line drug for estrogen-positive breast cancer following mastectomy in post-menopausal women.

Adverse effects of letrozole are due to the depletion of estrogen. The commonly seen adverse effects are hot flashes, vaginal dryness, nausea, diarrhea, dyspepsia, accelerated bone loss, and thinning of hair.



 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 1443 .

questions.text: 'A' kills 'B' with a knife. Another person 'C' saw 'A' with knife in the park few minutes before the murder. 'C' gives this statement in the court of law. What kind of evidence is this?
questions.solution:
• Direct evidence is a direct confirmation of a fact, such as a witness' testimony regarding what they personally witnessed, heard, or did.
  • Indirect evidence, such as circumstantial evidence, is proof of one or more facts from which another fact can be inferred.
  • In this case, 'C' did not witness the actual murder but observed 'A' with a knife in the park shortly before the incident. Therefore, the evidence indirectly suggests the possibility of 'A' being involved in the crime.
 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 9,13 .

questions.text: Fingerprints appear first at what gestational age?
questions.solution:
• Fingerprints begin to develop during the second trimester of pregnancy, specifically between 10-16 weeks of intrauterine life (IUL).
  • By 24 weeks of IUL, fingerprints are well-formed and unique to each individual. Therefore, the correct answer to your question would be option 2, which states that fingerprints appear first at 12-16 weeks of IUL.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 85-87 .

questions.text: Identify the mechanical injury shown in the picture.
questions.solution:
• Hesitation wounds, also known as hesitation marks, are shallow cuts or scratches that are often seen in cases of self-harm or attempted suicide. Hesitation wounds are so named because they are thought to be the result of hesitation or uncertainty on the part of the individual, who may be unsure about whether or not they want to carry out their suicidal or self-harming impulses.
  • They are superficial cuts or scratches on the skin that are typically smaller and less severe than the final self-inflicted wound. They are often irregular in shape and may appear shallow or jagged. Hesitation wounds are usually located near the intended site of the final wound, such as on the wrists or arms, and may be seen as an indicator of hesitation or ambivalence on the part of the individual.
 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 181,185,189,194 .

questions.text: Which among the following test is done to identify vaginal epithelial cells on the penis of an accused in a case of rape?
questions.solution:
Lugol's iodine is used to detect glycogen-rich vaginal epithelial cells that are stained dark brown when stained with lugol's iodine.
 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 426,434-436 .

The plant is commonly known as the "Mexican poppy" or "prickly poppy" and is a member of the poppy family. Its called "prickly poppy" because its seeds are present in prickly capsule
  • Its seed oil is sometimes used to adulterate mustard oil and cause epidemic dropsy

questions.text:
Symptoms seen in chronic arsenic poisoning are? 
(i) Aldrich Mee's line on nails 
(ii) Raindrop pigmentation 
(iii) Mixed Neuropathy 
(iv) Luminescent vomit 
(v) Bone marrow depression
questions.solution:
• Luminescent Vomit is not seen in Chronic arsenic poisoning - Its seen in phosphorus poisoning - rest all the features mentioned in the question are seen. 

The symptoms seen in chronic arsenic poisoning may include:

(i) Aldrich Mee's line on nails - This is a white line that appears on the nails and is caused by arsenic-induced damage to the nail bed.

(ii) Raindrop pigmentation -  Dark, irregularly shaped spots on the skin.

(iii) Mixed Neuropathy - This is a type of nerve damage that can cause tingling, numbness, and weakness in the limbs.

(iv) Bone marrow depression - Chronic exposure to arsenic can lead to bone marrow depression, which can cause anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

Other symptoms of chronic arsenic poisoning may include abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, nausea, headaches, confusion, and seizures.


Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 539,540 .

questions.text: Treatment of acute arsenic poisoning is by?
questions.solution:
Dimercaprol > EDTA 


The treatment of acute arsenic poisoning involves the use of chelating agents, which bind with arsenic and aid in its elimination from the body. The commonly used chelating agents for arsenic poisoning are:

  1. Dimercaprol (also known as British anti-lewisite or BAL): It is the first-line treatment for acute arsenic poisoning. Dimercaprol is administered by intramuscular injection and works by binding to arsenic and forming a complex that is excreted in the urine.

  2. Calcium EDTA (ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid): It is an alternative treatment for arsenic poisoning, particularly in cases where the use of dimercaprol is contraindicated or unavailable. Calcium EDTA works by binding to arsenic and other heavy metals and promoting their excretion in the urine.
     

    Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 517,518,539,540,544,556,592 .

questions.text: The manifestations of organophosphorus poisoning are all of the following except?
questions.solution:
• In organophosphorus poisoning, excessive cholinergic stimulation leads to miosis (pupil constriction) and pinpoint pupils ; not mydriasis
  • Organophosphates primarily affect the cholinergic system, leading to excessive cholinergic activity. The effects of organophosphates on the body include symptoms such as excessive salivation, lacrimation (tearing), urination, and defecation, which are collectively known as SLUD syndrome. Excessive cholinergic activity also causes bradycardia and bronchoconstriction. 
 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 522,539,602,603,631 .

choices.text: Tingling and numbness of hand and feet

questions.text: Which of the following is not the feature of cocaine intoxication?
questions.solution:
• Constricted pupils (miosis) and bradycardia (slow heart rate) are not typical features of cocaine intoxication.
  • In fact, cocaine tends to cause pupil dilation (mydriasis) and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) as part of its stimulant effects on the sympathetic nervous system.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 34th edition, Page no 602-603 .

questions.text: Which of the following poisoning will predominantly cause hypertension?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, the poisoning that predominantly causes hypertension is Cocaine. 

Cocaine poisoning:
1. Cocaine is a potent stimulant and sympathomimetic that affects the central nervous system and cardiovascular system.
2. It acts by inhibiting the reuptake of neurotransmitters such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin, leading to their accumulation in the synaptic clefts.
3. The excess catecholamines, particularly norepinephrine, contribute to the increased sympathetic activity, vasoconstriction, and subsequent hypertension.
 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 522,539,602,603,631 .

choices.text: Respiratory symptoms like rhinorrhea, bronchorrhea and bronchospasm

questions.text: Most characteristic muscarinic symptom produced in organophosphorus poisoning?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, the most characteristic muscarinic symptom produced in organophosphorus poisoning is 1. Respiratory symptoms like rhinorrhea, bronchorrhea, and bronchospasm.

Organophosphorus compounds inhibit the activity of the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which leads to an accumulation of acetylcholine at the muscarinic receptors in the body. This excessive stimulation of muscarinic receptors results in a variety of symptoms known as the cholinergic toxidrome.

Respiratory symptoms such as rhinorrhea (runny nose), bronchorrhea (excessive mucus production in the bronchi), and bronchospasm (constriction of the airway) are particularly characteristic of muscarinic receptor stimulation seen in organophosphorus poisoning. These symptoms arise due to the activation of muscarinic receptors in the respiratory system.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 516,521,522,523 .

questions.text: The action of the superior oblique muscle is?
questions.solution:
Intorsion is the primary and depression/abduction is the secondary/tertiary action of the Superior Oblique.



 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 349,350,351,352 .

questions.text: Which of the following traid is seen associated with angle closure glaucoma?
questions.solution:
The triad associated with angle closure glaucoma is 2. Vogt's triad.

Vogt's triad consists of three characteristic signs observed in angle closure glaucoma:

  1. Severe eye pain: Patients with angle closure glaucoma often experience intense eye pain due to increased intraocular pressure. The pain can be described as a deep, aching sensation.

  2. Nausea and vomiting: Angle closure glaucoma can cause gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea and vomiting. These symptoms are a result of the severe pain and autonomic nervous system involvement.

  3. Blurred vision or visual disturbances: Patients may experience blurred vision, halos around lights, or other visual disturbances. These visual symptoms are typically transient and occur during acute episodes of increased intraocular pressure.

Hutchinson's triad (option 1) refers to a set of clinical features associated with congenital syphilis and includes interstitial keratitis, not specific to angle closure glaucoma.

Virchow's triad (option 3) describes the three factors contributing to the formation of thrombosis, which are venous stasis, hypercoagulability, and endothelial injury. This triad is not associated with angle closure glaucoma.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 231,246,247,248,250,251,253 .

questions.text: A patient presented to the hospital with lagophthalmos. On examination the patient was found to have orbicularis oculi paresis and decreased corneal sensations. Which of the following is most likely to be responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi paresis, and decreased corneal sensations in this patient is Mycobacterium leprae.

  • These symptoms are consistent with the ocular manifestations of Leprosy.
  • Leprosy is caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium leprae, which primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes.
  • Involvement of the facial nerve can lead to orbicularis oculi paresis, resulting in difficulty closing the eyelids completely (lagophthalmos).
  • The decreased corneal sensations can occur due to the neuropathy associated with leprosy.
 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 5,6,68,69,73,74,78,116,378,491,519 .

questions.text: Punched lesion in retina is caused by all except?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 3: Posterior staphyloma.

Punched lesions in the retina are typically seen in conditions that involve inflammation or developmental abnormalities. Let's review the given options:

  1. Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasmosis infection can cause punched lesions in the retina. It is a common cause of focal retinochoroiditis.

  2. Congenital rubella: Congenital rubella infection can lead to a triad of findings known as the "congenital rubella syndrome," which includes cataracts, deafness, and retinopathy. The retinopathy in congenital rubella can present with punched lesions.

  3. Posterior staphyloma: Posterior staphyloma is a structural abnormality of the eyeball where there is a bulging or elongation of the posterior segment. It is not associated with punched lesions in the retina.

  4. Choroidal coloboma: Choroidal coloboma is a congenital defect in the choroid layer of the eye. It can be associated with punched lesions in the retina.

    Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 150,170,546 .

questions.text:
A lady presented with sudden painless loss of vision in the right eye one day back. On examination right eye has relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) while other ocular examinations were normal. What investigations should be done next to make the diagnosis 
(i) MRI brain and orbit with contrast 
(ii) Estimation of blood glucose, RFT and LFT 
(iii) Anti NMO and MOG antibody 
(iv) Thyroid profile
questions.solution:
Differential diagnosis of sudden painless loss of vision:
  • Hyphema
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal Artery Occlusion
  • Retinal Vein Occlusion
  • Retinal Detachment
  • Optic Neuritis
Acute painless loss of vision and relative afferent pupillary defect on ocular examination is indicative of optic neuritis.
To confirm the diagnosis of Optic neuritis -(i) MRI brain and orbit with contrast and (iii) Anti NMO and MOG antibody are required. 
 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 329,330,3477 .

questions.text: A patient presented to emergency with acute vertigo and horizontal nystagmus. The slow component of the nystagmus is towards the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: What is the stage of the laryngeal carcinoma shown in the CT?

choices.text: Maximum dose is given in deltoid muscle

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about Rabies immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
The correct statement about Rabies immunoglobulin is: 20 IU/kg dose is given.

Rabies immunoglobulin is given along with the rabies vaccine to provide passive immunity against the rabies virus after exposure. The dose of Rabies immunoglobulin is 20 IU/kg body weight(HRIG, the dose is 40IU/kg for equine). It should be administered at the site of the bite and infiltrated into the wound as much as possible. If the full dose cannot be infiltrated, the remaining volume should be injected intramuscularly at a site distant from the vaccine administration.

The other statements mentioned are incorrect:

  1. Rabies immunoglobulin is most effective when given as soon as possible after exposure, ideally within 24 hours. However, it can still be beneficial even if administered later up to 7 days. 

  2. The maximum dose of Rabies immunoglobulin is not given in the deltoid muscle. It is usually infiltrated into the wound or administered intramuscularly at a site distant from the vaccine administration.

  3. Human Rabies immunoglobulin is preferred over equine immunoglobulin due to its lower risk of anaphylaxis.


    Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 305-306 .

questions.text: Which among the following is true about WHO-SAGE criteria HPV vaccination in 9-14 years of age?
questions.solution:
WHO recommends: A one or two-dose schedule for girls aged 9-14 years. A one or two-dose schedule for girls and women aged 15-20 years. Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21 years.


 

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 3rd Edition, Page no 630 .

choices.text: Most important in the prevention of typhoid disease is immunization
Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply and personal hygiene are more important than immunization in typhoid prevention and control
Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that in TB

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about Typhoid disease?
questions.solution:
The correct statement about typhoid disease is: Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, and personal hygiene are more important than immunization in typhoid prevention and control.

Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. While immunization is an important preventive measure, it is not the most important aspect in the prevention and control of typhoid disease. The primary mode of transmission of typhoid is through contaminated food and water, usually from fecal contamination. Therefore, ensuring proper disposal of feces, a safe water supply, and practicing good personal hygiene, including handwashing, are crucial in preventing the spread of typhoid.

Statement 1 is incorrect because while immunization is important, it is not the most important aspect in prevention.

Statement 3 is incorrect because drug resistance in typhoid can be a significant issue, and multiple drug-resistant strains have emerged.

Statement 4 is incorrect because person-to-person transmission is the main mode of transmission for typhoid(Not 10%).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 258-260 .

questions.text: Best alternative to mother's breast milk in a low birth weight baby?
questions.solution:
The best alternative to a mother's breast milk in a low Birth Weight baby is human donor breast milk.
According to AIIMS NICU protocols:
All LBW babies should only receive breast milk from the mother or human donor irrespective of the mode of feeding.
 

Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 156,157 .

questions.text: A 1 year old child is brought to the hospital. He has received only a single dose of DPT at 6 weeks of his life. What would be done next about his DPT vaccinations?
questions.solution:
In a 1-year-old child who has received only a single dose of DPT (diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus) vaccine at 6 weeks of age, the appropriate next step would be:

  1. Give DPT 2nd dose.

The DPT vaccination schedule typically involves a primary series of three doses, usually given at 6 weeks, 10 weeks, and 14 weeks of age. Since the child has received only one dose so far, they would need to receive the second dose to continue the vaccination series.

Other options
Option (1) There is no need to restart vaccination from the beginning and give a full course.
Option (2) DT had to be given age >7 years, if the age is less than 7 years - DPT can be given.
Option (4) Child is incompletely immunized - pending doses of DPT need to be given.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 175 .

questions.text:
Which of the following requirements should be met to start a person on leprosy chemoprophylaxis? 
(i) Age > 2 years 
(ii) Living with the patient for >6 months 
(iii) Close contact for >20 hours per week 
(iv) Sharing the same clothes and towels
questions.solution:
Inclusion criteria to be considered for receiving Post-exposure Chemoprophylaxis with single dose Rifampicin in leprosy:

(i)Age > 2 years 
(ii)Living with the patient for >3 months in the past 1 year
(iii)Close contact for >20 hours per week (eg sharing clothes)

Hence, option (3) is correct( [ii] is wrong - it should be 3 months, not 6)

Exclusion Criteria
(i) Pregnancy
(ii) Received Rifampicin in the past 2 years(eg for TB)
(iii) Signs and symptoms of TB
(iv) Signs and symptoms of Leprosy
(v) Acute febrile illness. 
(vi) History of hepatic disorder
 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 366.

questions.text: A patient with satellite skin lesion presents to the hospital. He also has one hypopigmented lesion and one thickened nerve. The treatment best suited would be?
questions.solution:
It is a case of Leprosy with 1 hypo-pigmented Lesion and 1 thickened Nerve making it a paucibacillary leprosy case and the treatment would be multi-drug therapy for 6 months. 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 366 .

questions.text: Which of the following immunization is done in elderly/ geriatric population?
questions.solution:

  • Rotavirus vaccine, Haemophilus influenza B vaccine, and Diphtheria toxoid are all recommended in childhood.

questions.text: Endogenous transmission of which of the following disease is found in India?
questions.solution:
• Endogenous transmission of Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) is found in India (Option 2).
 
  • CCHF is a viral disease caused by the Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever virus. Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) is primarily transmitted to humans through the bite of infected ticks (Genus Hyalomma)
  • In India, the presence of CCHF was confirmed for the first time in Gujarat as a nosocomial outbreak in 2011. Since then, multiple outbreaks/sporadic cases have been reported from different districts of Gujarat. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 520, 531, 562, 661.

questions.text:
A woman has 2 children- Ram and Shyam. One fine day Shyam developed measles having fever with rash. After 4 days of this, Ram also developed the same symptom complex. Ram was then reported to the village sub-center. Which among the following is the correct statement? 
(i) Ram is the index case 
(ii) Shyamm is the primary case 
(iii) Ram got infected by Shyam 
(iv) If the mother had reported when Shyam got infected, Ram could have been vaccinated.
questions.solution:
The correct statements are : (i), (ii), (iii), (iv)

Explanation:

1. Ram is the index case because he was the first case to be reported to the health authorities. 
2. Shyam is the primary case because he was the first to develop measles symptoms.
3. Ram got infected by Shyam because he developed the same symptoms after Shyam.
4. If the mother had reported when Shyam got infected, Ram could have been vaccinated, which would have potentially prevented him from getting infected.

Therefore, option 4 is the correct answer.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 164-168.

questions.text: Confidence interval is not increased by which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Confidence Interval for a Population Mean (Z-Interval):  Formula= X ± Z * (σ / √n)

  • The confidence interval is inversely proportional to sample size(n) - hence increasing sample size will decrease confidence interval. 
Abbreviation in Formula 
  • X: Sample mean
  • Z: Z-score corresponding to the desired confidence level
  • σ: Population standard deviation (known or estimated from the sample)
  • n: Sample size



Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health 4th Edition , Page no 19 .

choices.text: Physician should not emphasize much on the communication
Treat the patient regardless of the patient's perception
Due emphasis should be given to patients cultural background

questions.text: India is a diverse country with a wealth of different cultures and languages. Correct statement among the following?
questions.solution:
The correct statement among the options provided is:

3. Due emphasis should be given to the patient's cultural background.

India's diversity extends to its cultural and linguistic aspects. When providing healthcare services, it is essential for physicians to recognize and respect the cultural background of their patients. This includes understanding their beliefs, customs, and practices that may impact their healthcare decisions and preferences. By giving due emphasis to a patient's cultural background, healthcare providers can ensure that care is provided in a culturally sensitive and appropriate manner, promoting effective communication and patient-centered care.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 918 .

questions.text: Methods used to describe collection of data are included under?
questions.solution:
The methods used to describe a collection of data are included under "Descriptive Statistics" (Option 3). Descriptive statistics involve organizing, summarizing, and presenting data in a meaningful way. This includes measures such as central tendency (mean, median, mode), measures of dispersion (range, variance, standard deviation), graphical representations (histograms, bar charts, scatter plots), and other techniques that provide a summary and description of the data.

 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 78 .

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding genetic screening of the newborn? 
(i) Screening tests define the risk of transmission of a genetic disorder 
(ii) Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests
(iii) Screening of a disease requires genetic mapping 
(iv) Screening always involves invasive procedure.
questions.solution:
Among the given statements, the true statement regarding genetic screening of the newborn is:

(i) Screening tests define the risk of transmission of a genetic disorder.

Genetic screening tests for newborns are designed to identify the risk or presence of certain genetic disorders. They aim to identify newborns who may have an increased risk of developing or carrying genetic conditions. These tests can provide information about the likelihood of a genetic disorder being transmitted from the parents to the newborn. However, it is important to note that screening tests do not provide a definitive diagnosis of a genetic disorder but rather assess the risk or probability. 

The other statements are not true:

(ii) Diagnostic tests are typically more accurate than screening tests. Screening tests identify individuals who have an increased risk of a specific condition, while diagnostic tests confirm or rule out a specific condition.

(iii) Genetic mapping is not always required for screening tests. Genetic screening tests may utilize various methods.

(iv) Screening tests do not always involve invasive procedures. In fact, many newborn genetic screening tests can be conducted using non-invasive methods, such as a blood sample obtained from a heel prick.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 148 .
