questions.text: A 34 year old woman landed in AIIMS emergency after RTA with GCS-3. She was intubated and sent for NCCT, which was found to be normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI). DAI is a type of traumatic brain injury that occurs due to rapid acceleration or deceleration forces, such as those experienced in an RTA. It often leads to widespread damage throughout the brain, particularly affecting the white matter.

The patient's Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 3 indicates a severe level of impairment, which is commonly associated with DAI. Additionally, the fact that the non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) scan was normal does not rule out DAI, as it is not always detectable in imaging studies immediately following the injury.

SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage), EDH (Epidural Hematoma), and cerebral contusion are also possible diagnoses in the context of head trauma, but they may present with different clinical features or imaging findings.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 365-368 .

questions.text: What is the least useful investigation to confirm the diagnosis in a patient with the following condition as shown in the image?

24-hour pH monitoring is an investigation used to detect gastroesophageal reflux, post achalasia cardia treatment- not for diagnosis of achalasia.

questions.text: Following blunt trauma to chest, patient presents to the casualty. Out of the following radiographs, in which case further evaluation needs to be done before putting a chest tube in the patient?

CXR(1) Confluent opacity in the lower lobe of the left lung - suggestive of hemothorax in the setting of trauma. 
CXR(2) shows bowel in the thoracic cavity - suggestive of diaphragmatic rupture. 
Hence in (1) and (2) - further evaluation is needed before putting a chest tube. 

 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 323,367,368,370,920 .

choices.text: Amputation may be needed in severe cases

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct about management of severe frostbite?
questions.solution:
The correct statement about the management of severe frostbite is:

  1. Amputation may be needed in severe cases.

Severe frostbite can cause significant tissue damage, including necrosis (tissue death), which may require surgical intervention, such as amputation, to remove non-viable tissue and prevent further complications.

The other statements are not accurate:

  1. Cold compression is not the mainstay of treatment for severe frostbite. Initially, rewarming the affected area in a controlled manner is the primary goal of treatment.

  2. Rewarming is essential in the management of frostbite. It should be done using warm water (37-39°C) in a controlled environment by healthcare professionals.

  3. Analgesics (pain medications) are often necessary to manage pain associated with frostbite. Antibiotics may also be prescribed if there is evidence of infection or if there is a risk of infection due to tissue damage.


    Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no3633-3635.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements regarding split graft and full thickness skin graft? 
(i) Primary contraction more with split skin graft 
(ii) Secondary contraction more with split skin graft 
(iii) Primary contraction more with full thickness skin graft 
(iv) Secondary contraction more with full thickness skin graft
questions.solution:
The correct statements are:

(ii) Secondary contraction more with a split skin graft.
(iii) Primary contraction more with full-thickness skin graft.

Explanation:
Primary contraction refers to the immediate shrinkage that occurs after graft placement. Full-thickness skin grafts involve the transplantation of both the epidermis and the entire dermis. As a result, full-thickness grafts generally undergo more primary contraction compared to split-thickness grafts. Split skin grafts have more secondary contraction. 




Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page no 1917 .

questions.text: A patient came with a complaint of a mass in the right hypochondrium and severe itching and jaundice which was waxing and waning. He also had a history of 2 episodes of black stools. Surgery was done as shown in the image. Which among the following condition was operated here?
questions.solution:
• The most likely condition operated in this case is periampullary carcinoma. The location of the mass in the right hypochondrium, along with symptoms such as severe itching, jaundice (waxing and waning), and episodes of black stools, are suggestive of a periampullary tumor.
  • The term "periampullary carcinoma" refers to tumors that arise in the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater, which is where the common bile duct and pancreatic duct join and empty into the small intestine. Periampullary carcinomas can include tumors arising from the ampulla of Vater itself, the distal common bile duct, the head of the pancreas, or the duodenum.
  • Whipple surgery, also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy is depicted in the image. It is a surgical procedure commonly performed to treat periampullary carcinomas. 
 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1284 .

questions.text: Nutritional complications are more with which of the following fistula?
questions.solution:
• Fistulas allow intestinal contents to leave the body, and the distal intestine/colon is not included in the absorption process.
  • Patients lose macronutrients, hydration, and electrolytes as a result of proximal small intestine fistula and hence are at much higher risk of nutritional complications. 
 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1315 .

questions.text: A 35 year old women was on tamoxifen therapy for 5 years now after breast cancer surgery. When should she discontinue the drug if she wants to conceive?
questions.solution:
• Tamoxifen can be started either after surgery (adjuvant therapy) or before surgery (neoadjuvant therapy).
  • When given after surgery, it is usually taken in the dose of 10mg BD for 5 years. It's the DOC for hormonal therapy in premenopausal women. It is teratogenic in nature.
  • Ideally, it should be stopped 2 months before conception which is the washout time of the drug in order to prevent its teratogenic effects.

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 812 .

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient presented with Rectal prolapse. Which among the following is not a perineal approach management for the condition?
questions.solution:
• Ripstein procedure is not a perineal approach; it is an abdominal surgical technique used for the treatment of rectal prolapse. In the Ripstein procedure, the rectum is permanently fixed to the presacral fascia using polypropylene mesh. This eliminates intussusception and prolapse while restoring the rectum's natural posterior curve.
  • On the other hand, the other options mentioned, Altmeier, Thiersch, and Delorme, are perineal approaches for the management of rectal prolapse.
 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1399 .

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective oral drug for smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
• Varenicline is a medication specifically developed to aid in smoking cessation.
  • Varenicline acts as a partial agonist at α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the mesolimbic system(pleasure pathway).
  • As a partial agonist, it stimulates these receptors to a lesser degree than nicotine itself leading to a moderate release of dopamine in the brain. This action helps to reduce nicotine cravings and withdrawal symptoms.
  • But being a partial agonist and binding to Nicotine receptors, it blocks the binding of nicotine. This activity prevents nicotine from fully activating the receptors, reducing the pleasurable effects of smoking.
 

Reference : Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 185-188,437 .

questions.text: Most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine?
questions.solution:
• Paradiscal is the most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine. 
  • In paradisical lesions, the infection spreads via the arterial plexus. It starts from the anterior vertebral body adjacent to the end plate, involving the disc, and causes disc destruction.
  • With further progression, anterior wedging of the vertebra occurs with resultant kyphosis.

questions.text: 5-alpha reductase inhibitor is indicated to?
questions.solution:
• A 5-alpha reductase inhibitor is indicated to reduce intracellular Dihydrotestosterone (DHT).
  • The enzyme 5-alpha reductase converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a more potent form of testosterone. By inhibiting this enzyme, 5-alpha reductase inhibitors reduce the conversion of testosterone to DHT, leading to lower levels of intracellular DHT.
  • Lowering intracellular DHT is the primary therapeutic effect of 5-alpha reductase inhibitors, and it is utilized in the treatment of certain conditions such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and androgenetic alopecia (male pattern baldness).
 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 494,840-842 .

questions.text:
On investigation for infertility in a couple, the male partner was found to have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Which of the following findings are true in this condition?

(ii) Low LH, Low FSH 
(iii) Low LH, High FSH 
(iv) Low testosterone 
(v) Low prolactin levels
questions.solution:
The correct findings in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism are:
(i) Azoospermia/Severe oligospermia
(ii) Low LH, Low FSH, and 
(iv) Low testosterone.

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is characterized by low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) in the blood. These hormones are essential for stimulating the production of testosterone ---> low levels would result in low testosterone and later low sperm count.

questions.text:
Arrange the following components in spermatogenesis from adluminal to luminal 
(A) Myoepithelial cells 
(B) Spermatogonia 
(C) Primary spermatocyte 
(D) Spermatid 
(E) Secondary spermatocyte
questions.solution:
The correct arrangement of the components in spermatogenesis from adluminal to luminal  is as follows:

(A) Myoepithelial cells - These cells are located near the basal lamina and have contractile properties that help in the movement of spermatozoa.

(B) Spermatogonia - These are the germ cells that reside close to the basal lamina and undergo mitotic division to maintain the germ cell population.

(C) Primary spermatocyte - These cells are formed through the differentiation of spermatogonia 

(E) Secondary spermatocytes - These are the result of the meiotic division of primary spermatocytes 

(D) Spermatid - These cells are formed through the differentiation of secondary spermatocytes 

Therefore, the correct arrangement from adluminal to luminal is Myoepithelial cells (A) - Spermatogonia (B) - Primary spermatocyte (C) - Secondary spermatocyte (E) - Spermatid (D).





Reference: Langman's Medical Embryology, 14th edition, Page no 29-31.

questions.text: Which amongst these is the age distribution for vulval carcinoma?
questions.solution:
• The age distribution for vulval carcinoma is commonly seen in the following range: 55-85 years
  • Most commonly diagnosed at ages 65 to 74, with the median age at diagnosis of 69 years. Vulval carcinoma can occur at any age, although it is less common in younger women.

questions.text: Congenital absence of seminal vesicles and Vas deferens is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
• Congenital absence of seminal vesicles and vas deferens is typically seen in Cystic fibrosis (option 1).
 
  • Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that affects various organs, including the lungs, pancreas, liver, and reproductive system. It is caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene present on chromosome 7. The CFTR protein is responsible for chloride conductance across the epithelium and for the production of mucus, sweat, and digestive fluids.
 
  • In males with cystic fibrosis, one common manifestation is the absence or bilateral aplasia (underdevelopment) of the seminal vesicles and vas deferens. This condition is known as Congenital Bilateral Absence of the Vas Deferens (CBAVD).


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2298.

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2896, 3001.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Best indicator for the adequacy of ventilation as per NRP?
questions.solution:
• The best indicator for the adequacy of ventilation in neonatal resuscitation, according to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) guidelines, is the improvement in heart rate (HR).
  • During neonatal resuscitation, the primary goal is to establish effective ventilation and support the baby's oxygenation. While all the options provided can be important signs of adequate ventilation, the improvement in heart rate is the most reliable and crucial indicator of successful ventilation.

When effective ventilation is achieved, the baby's heart rate should increase or improve.


 Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 130,131 .

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy weighing 15 kg and 100 cm tall with blood urea 100mg/dl and serum creatinine 1 mg/dl is admitted in the Pediatric Nephrology ward. Calculate the eGFR of the patient. 
1. 33ml/min/ 1.73 m2
2. 80 ml/min/1.73 m2
3. 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 
4. 65ml/min/1.73m2
questions.solution:
In children, the most frequently used creatinine-based eGFR equation is the revised bedside Schwartz: 
0.413 × Height (cm) / Serum Cr (mg/dL).

Using the given values:

Height = 100 cm Serum creatinine = 1 mg/dl k = 0.413

eGFR = 0.41 × (100 cm) / (1 mg/dl) = 41 ml/min/1.73 m2 



Reference: Nelson Textbook Of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 2715,2716 .

questions.text: A 52 year old patient with diabetes presented with palpitation. On examination the BP was 128/78 mmHg. The ECG of the patient is given below. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
• The given ECG shows narrow complex tachycardia with absent P waves and regular rhythm suggestive of PSVT.
  • Adenosine is the drug of choice in hemodynamically stable patients. (Synchronised Cardioversion if unstable). It's used for the acute termination of PSVT. It works by briefly blocking conduction in the atrioventricular (AV) node, which can interrupt the reentrant circuit responsible for the tachycardia.
  • Adenosine is usually administered as a rapid intravenous (IV) bolus under medical supervision.
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1898,1899 .

questions.text: Which of the following clinical presentation is not seen in any lesion to the spinal cord?

  • Crossed hemiplegia is characterized by the presence of LMN type of cranial nerve palsy on one side and hemiplegia on the other side. It is usually seen in brain stem lesions.

choices.text: It is a complete section of the spinal cord
Pain & temperature sensation on the controlateral side is impaired
Complete sensory loss on the ipsilateral side

questions.text: Which among the following statement is wrong about Brown sequard syndrome?
questions.solution:
The wrong statement about Brown-Séquard syndrome among the options provided is:

1. It is a complete section of the spinal cord.

The Brown-Séquard syndrome is not characterized by a complete section or transection of the spinal cord. Instead, it is typically caused by a hemisection or incomplete lesion of the spinal cord, resulting in specific neurological deficits.

The correct features of Brown-Séquard syndrome are:

2. Pain and temperature sensation on the contralateral side are impaired: There is a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the side opposite the lesion due to the decussation (crossing) of these sensory fibers in the spinal cord.

3. Complete sensory loss on the ipsilateral side: There is a loss of proprioception, fine touch, vibration sensation, and two-point discrimination on the side of the lesion (ipsilateral side).

4. Fine touch and vibration sensation on the ipsilateral side are impaired: Due to the interruption of the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway on the ipsilateral side, fine touch and vibration sensation are affected on the side of the lesion.

It's important to note that motor function can also be affected in Brown-Séquard syndrome. There is ipsilateral (same side) motor weakness or paralysis due to damage to the corticospinal tract on the same side as the lesion.
 



 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3446 .

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of severe malaria?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, pH > 7.35 (option 1) is not a feature typically associated with Severe malaria.

Severe malaria refers to severe manifestations of the disease that can be life-threatening and often require immediate medical intervention. Common features of complicated malaria include severe anemia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury, cerebral malaria (which can present with coma or altered consciousness), metabolic acidosis, and hypoglycemia.

A pH greater than 7.35 indicates a relatively normal or slightly alkaline blood pH, which is not typically associated with severe malaria. In severe cases, metabolic acidosis is more likely to be observed with a decreased pH.

Unarousable coma (option 2), glucose < 40 mg/dl (option 3), and serum creatinine of 5.2 mg/dl (option 4) are all features that can be associated with severe malaria.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1724, table 224-2 .

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in the emergency treatment of hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Magnesium Sulfate is not used in the emergency treatment of hyperkalemia. Rest all are used. 



 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 352-355 .

questions.text: Tongue fascination is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Tongue fasciculation is a common symptom of spinal muscular atrophy (SMA). Muscle denervation in SMA contributes to the involuntary muscle contractions and twitching seen in fasciculations.

SMA is typically caused by genetic mutations in the survival motor neuron 1 (SMN1) gene, which is responsible for producing a protein called survival motor neuron (SMN). Insufficient levels of the SMN protein result in the degeneration and loss of motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy.

Note: Drugs used for the treatment of SMA can be asked in future INI-CET exams (Trial of Spinraza is ongoing at AIIMS, Delhi)



 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3415,3501,3509,3510,3521 .

questions.text: A patient presented to the hospital with lesions as shown below.  He had a prodrome of fever, malaise, excruciating burning pain, and later an outbreak of lesions as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem and image showing the dermatomal distribution of lesions point toward Herpes zoster. The classical feature of herpes zoster lesions is their distribution along a dermatome on Chest/Buttock or Face.


Reference : Rook’s Textbook Of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no 128.1, 129.1, 25.1 .

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly seen only in females?
questions.solution:
• Rett syndrome is the only condition given above that is most commonly seen in females.(X linked dominant disorder)
  • Rett syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by a mutation in the MECP2 gene.
  • It is characterized by a period of normal development followed by a regression in skills, including loss of purposeful hand use, repetitive hand movements, gait abnormalities, and intellectual disability. Rett syndrome is almost exclusively seen in females, with an estimated incidence of 1 in 10,000-15,000 live births.

Asperger syndrome, atypical autism, and classical autism are all neurodevelopmental disorders that can affect both males and females. However, males are more likely to be diagnosed with these conditions than females.



Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1124, 1164, 1167, 1261.

choices.text: Bipolar I have equal prevalence in males & females & Bipolar II is more common in females
Most common age of onset is in the 35-45 years age group

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Bipolar disorders except?
questions.solution:
Statement (3) is an incorrect statement. 
  • The most common age of onset for bipolar disorder is late adolescence to early adulthood (15-25 years of age group).
  • Bipolar disorder typically emerges in individuals during their late teens or early twenties, although it can occur at any age.
  • Onset after the age of 50 is considered late-onset bipolar disorder

Reference : Kaplan And Sadock’s Concise Textbook Of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no 347-349, 377 .

questions.text: A 49 year old male with history of alcohol consumption for many years developed liver cirrhosis. LFT of the patient shows GGT: 563 u/L, AST:180 u/L, ALT 150 u/L. Now he has stopped consumption. Which of the following is the most suitable drug to be given to avoid withdrawal symptoms?
questions.solution:
• An alcoholic who has recently stopped consuming is at very high risk for withdrawal symptoms. The DOC for prevention/treatment of alcohol withdrawal is Benzodiazepines. However, in the above scenario - the patient also has features s/o CLD and cirrhosis, and most benzodiazepines being metabolized by the liver are contraindicated. 
  • Among the options provided, Lorazepam (option 1) would be the most suitable choice in this situation. Lorazepam is primarily metabolized in the liver, but it undergoes glucuronidation, which is a different metabolic pathway compared to other benzodiazepines that undergo oxidative metabolism. This means that lorazepam is less dependent on liver enzymes and may have a lower risk of accumulation in individuals with liver impairment. 


Benzodiazepines safe in hepatic failure 

Outside  - Oxazepam
The - Temazepam
Liver - Lorazepam

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3561 .

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese man presented with lethargy & sleepiness during day time. A polysomnography was taken and is given below. Which stage of sleep the marked part of the graph represent?
questions.solution:
The area marked in polysomnography shows positive REOG and LEOG.
Positive electrooculogram and Sawtooth EEG in the area corresponding to it is characteristic of REM sleep.


Reference : Kaplan and Sadock’s Concise Textbook Of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no 534 .
